blog.name: ontaskvvidogast
blog.title: Welcome
blog.description: Imma big fan of art and stories. Current obsession is Critical Role. MIGHTY NEIN! Some marvel stuff will occasionally slip through into this blog, but my side blog is artloife for other misc things. Icon credit to cyborg_cinders.

summary: Quotes from C2E57 that are still destroying me hours later...
title: Quotes from C2E57 that are still destroying me hours later...
body:
(as best as I could transcribe them)

Leylas Krynn: Travelers from the Empire, who renounce their home and history…I have some questions.

Caleb to the Queen: This is my friend, Nott the Brave. Her husband is in this kingdom… we are but small pieces on this gameboard… but Nott’s husband… we’re hoping to take him back, and I hope this offering makes that easier to do.

Nott to the Queen: Surely even someone of your great stature can realize… reuniting a family, with their child, is the greatest thing any mother could ask for.

That one badass sounding goblin: I am Sky Syyvil Abriana Miriam, Leader of Den Miriam. I have lived nearly as long as Leylas, and I am a keeper of the history.

Fjord to the Queen: I think I speak for all of us in saying there’s no way we could even begin to imagine what you’ve seen over 1200 years… I’m sure we’d be honored to learn, if you would.

Caleb: Umavi, I beseech you…the fact that we have brought what we’ve brought to you, I hope shows… that our people are able to change, and shake off the bonds we have grown up under.

Deucey to the Queen: This object could have been lost forever, in the practical thinking of war.

Beau to the Queen: For a woman so adherent to cycles, I believe you have the power to break them.

Beau to the Nein, in the antechamber after: And that slavery stuff?? We’re not doing that anymore. That was stupid. Doing that in a place where it was literally robbing me of my voice? Not super cool.

Fjord to Nott: But what do we know? I know we just talked to a woman that was 1200 years old, that’s probably lived a million different lives! And a goblin that’s been like… 999,000…

Fjord, again, later, about the gods and the city: I mean they weren’t good right? Betrayer is inherently bad!

Nott: But they changed the name! Maybe they didn’t like it either.

Fjord: Sure, sure… I’m sure there wasn’t nothin left behind.

Jester: Don’t judge people based on their parents!

Fjord to Nott later, about the drinking: You’re all the woman you need to be!

Nott: I’m scared!

Jester: But you love him! You don’t want to be drunk when you meet him again!

Caleb to Nott, before meeting Yeza: If it’s any help, you’re not alone, no matter what happens, we’ll be here for you.

Jester to Yeza: Sometimes we look different, but in our hearts, we are still very much the same.

(beat)

Yeza: Do you have any food or water?

Jester to Yeza later, in warning: I’ll cut you

****Nott and Yeza moments!!***

Y: You’re alive?

N: I am, yes.

Y: Then that’s the best news I’ve heard in a long time.

A couple moments later, as they first touch:

N: It’s weird right?

Y: Maybe, but you’re warm.

Yeza to Nott when she says she’s afraid: What are you scared of now? You made it all the way here. And I know what that took… You’re braver than I could ever be.

Later still, about the gold:

Nott to Yeza: Chemistry’s great baby, but killing’s better.

Yeza, delighted: I have a mercenary for a wife?!

******

Caleb: I think we should stop a war.

Yeza: I’m just a country boy… I don’t know what you’ve been through… but don’t lose sight of the simple folk, please.

Caleb to Fjord: Well, when I see my friends are in danger of dying, I am not going to standby and do nothing.

Jester to Beau later, about romance and the books they’ve read: Are they like porn though… Or is that how relationships actually are?

(beat)

Beau: Ooooooooh

Yasha, to Caduceus: Sometimes tragedy gives perspective.

Deucey: I believe in destiny. I believe we’re called upon to do great work, or small works sometimes.

Caleb to Beauregard, the next morning: I need you to be my friend…I care for you.

Caleb, again: I think we could do some good. We could really do some good.

Beau: I think that’s the best retribution for Caleb Widogast. Doing some good.

Caleb, again: I think we could do some good. We could really do some good.

Beau: I think that’s the best retribution for Caleb Widogast. Doing some good.

summary: Weird... I wouldn't have guessed. Though I'm pretty much a 3 way split between Nott, Caleb, and Fjord. I feel a bit called out.
body:
Which Member of The Mighty Nein are You?

Weird… I wouldn’t have guessed. Though I’m pretty much a 3 way split between Nott, Caleb, and Fjord. I feel a bit called out.

blog.name: yfere
blog.title: just muddling through
blog.description: Alcin, 22. they/them. Critical Role and assorted nonsense

summary: “Hey, I didn’t say it. Um. It took a brass pair to do what you did, so um. Thanks for, you know, not getting us killed I guess.”
body:
All right, so diving back into this before the Big Jester Meta, a reply of sorts to @comehomenell‘s post theorizing an “Aaron Burr” moment with Fjord and Caleb, which is interesting.

I’ve been thinking about this some more, and I was struck by Fjord’s wording when he says:

“Hey, I didn’t say it. Um. It took a brass pair to do what you did, so um. Thanks for, you know, not getting us killed I guess.”

Because there’s a lot going on here. One, he is thanking and complimenting Caleb–he doesn’t have to, Caleb is trying to end the conversation, and Caleb was never asking to be thanked in the first place. If anything Caleb was asking for reassurance that they were on the same page when he brought up the “callback,” saying, this was a risk, you also take risks, I like that about you, we are the same, right, this is okay?

Which brings me to what I find most interesting about the statement, that Fjord is saying thanks for “not getting us killed.” A phrasing which implies that he’s thanking Caleb, not exactly for the fact that his move saved them, but that his action paid off and didn’t “get” the Mighty Nein killed on the spot–that Caleb’s actions didn’t result in their deaths. Which recalls the other part of the risk-taking conversation they had–Fjord is a gambler, yes, but he always at least intends his gambles to only affect him personally. He gambles his own funds and his own funds alone, he is exceedingly careful and cautious with the interests of everyone else, dissembling and holding back as much as possible from getting them involved in his own troubles. But Caleb has always been behind the concept that Fjord, himself, and everyone else should take risks using not only their own resources, but the entire group’s.  He’s always been behind the concept that everyone should solve everyone else’s problems at all times in the group. Caleb would have been fine if Fjord had gambled the funds of the party. And he’s fine, hopes Fjord is fine with that he gambled a little with the lives of the entire party when he made his move. Caleb tried to focus attention on himself, yes, he was being as smart as he could possibly be in his choices, but it was still a gamble, one that Caleb chose to take and Fjord did not, could not. They are not on the same page in this, not really in the way Caleb is hoping.

I still don’t know what to make of the “I guess.” When I first heard it I thought it sounded like passive aggression, buried resentment or a barb. But rewatching it I think it’s also possible it was just awkwardness, so….I really don’t know. But Fjord’s situation is an interesting one, because despite being happy to be alive and not in jail, despite getting Nott’s husband back safely and cleanly, despite being excited about learning more and having new options and potentially strong alliances, despite really having nothing but suspicions things might go badly in the future, despite everything about what Caleb did working out as well as could possibly be hoped for–there’s still  a sense that something doesn’t sit right about it, about Caleb making that gamble for all of them.

And it makes me curious too, about more about what he’s thinking. Does he realize that inaction is also a choice? How does he feel about the concept that not taking the gamble would have made things so much more dire for them, might very well have gotten them killed as well? How much does he realize that every choice that he’s made in the group has inevitably affected them all, whether he’s intended it to or not–is he comfortable with that idea, or does he still think he can avoid involving them in the future? Will he ever open up entirely to the idea of making his problems the group’s problems, and vice versa? When Caleb says he couldn’t possibly stand idly by while their lives were in danger and there was something he could do, Fjord is silent. If he were to reply, what would he say?

Caleb would have been fine if Fjord had gambled the funds of the party. And he’s fine, hopes Fjord is fine with that he gambled a little with the lives of the entire party when he made his move. Caleb tried to focus attention on himself, yes, he was being as smart as he could possibly be in his choices, but it was still a gamble, one that Caleb chose to take and Fjord did not, could not. They are not on the same page in this, not really in the way Caleb is hoping.

I still don’t know what to make of the “I guess.” When I first heard it I thought it sounded like passive aggression, buried resentment or a barb. But rewatching it I think it’s also possible it was just awkwardness, so….I really don’t know. But Fjord’s situation is an interesting one, because despite being happy to be alive and not in jail, despite getting Nott’s husband back safely and cleanly, despite being excited about learning more and having new options and potentially strong alliances, despite really having nothing but suspicions things might go badly in the future, despite everything about what Caleb did working out as well as could possibly be hoped for–there’s still  a sense that something doesn’t sit right about it, about Caleb making that gamble for all of them.

And it makes me curious too, about more about what he’s thinking. Does he realize that inaction is also a choice? How does he feel about the concept that not taking the gamble would have made things so much more dire for them, might very well have gotten them killed as well? How much does he realize that every choice that he’s made in the group has inevitably affected them all, whether he’s intended it to or not–is he comfortable with that idea, or does he still think he can avoid involving them in the future? Will he ever open up entirely to the idea of making his problems the group’s problems, and vice versa? When Caleb says he couldn’t possibly stand idly by while their lives were in danger and there was something he could do, Fjord is silent. If he were to reply, what would he say?
trail.content:
All right, so diving back into this before the Big Jester Meta, a reply of sorts to @comehomenell‘s post theorizing an “Aaron Burr” moment with Fjord and Caleb, which is interesting.

I’ve been thinking about this some more, and I was struck by Fjord’s wording when he says:

“Hey, I didn’t say it. Um. It took a brass pair to do what you did, so um. Thanks for, you know, not getting us killed I guess.”

Because there’s a lot going on here. One, he is thanking and complimenting Caleb–he doesn’t have to, Caleb is trying to end the conversation, and Caleb was never asking to be thanked in the first place. If anything Caleb was asking for reassurance that they were on the same page when he brought up the “callback,” saying, this was a risk, you also take risks, I like that about you, we are the same, right, this is okay?

Which brings me to what I find most interesting about the statement, that Fjord is saying thanks for “not getting us killed.” A phrasing which implies that he’s thanking Caleb, not exactly for the fact that his move saved them, but that his action paid off and didn’t “get” the Mighty Nein killed on the spot–that Caleb’s actions didn’t result in their deaths. Which recalls the other part of the risk-taking conversation they had–Fjord is a gambler, yes, but he always at least intends his gambles to only affect him personally. He gambles his own funds and his own funds alone, he is exceedingly careful and cautious with the interests of everyone else, dissembling and holding back as much as possible from getting them involved in his own troubles. But Caleb has always been behind the concept that Fjord, himself, and everyone else should take risks using not only their own resources, but the entire group’s.  He’s always been behind the concept that everyone should solve everyone else’s problems at all times in the group. Caleb would have been fine if Fjord had gambled the funds of the party. And he’s fine, hopes Fjord is fine with that he gambled a little with the lives of the entire party when he made his move. Caleb tried to focus attention on himself, yes, he was being as smart as he could possibly be in his choices, but it was still a gamble, one that Caleb chose to take and Fjord did not, could not. They are not on the same page in this, not really in the way Caleb is hoping.

I still don’t know what to make of the “I guess.” When I first heard it I thought it sounded like passive aggression, buried resentment or a barb. But rewatching it I think it’s also possible it was just awkwardness, so….I really don’t know. But Fjord’s situation is an interesting one, because despite being happy to be alive and not in jail, despite getting Nott’s husband back safely and cleanly, despite being excited about learning more and having new options and potentially strong alliances, despite really having nothing but suspicions things might go badly in the future, despite everything about what Caleb did working out as well as could possibly be hoped for–there’s still  a sense that something doesn’t sit right about it, about Caleb making that gamble for all of them.

And it makes me curious too, about more about what he’s thinking. Does he realize that inaction is also a choice? How does he feel about the concept that not taking the gamble would have made things so much more dire for them, might very well have gotten them killed as well? How much does he realize that every choice that he’s made in the group has inevitably affected them all, whether he’s intended it to or not–is he comfortable with that idea, or does he still think he can avoid involving them in the future? Will he ever open up entirely to the idea of making his problems the group’s problems, and vice versa? When Caleb says he couldn’t possibly stand idly by while their lives were in danger and there was something he could do, Fjord is silent. If he were to reply, what would he say?
